Indian #1 draws aside a branch and is faced with a hor- rific stone sculpture of a Chachapoyan demon.  The Indian is so frightened no sound comes out when he screams.  He turns and runs silently away. Indian #2 calls to his friend.  Getting no response, he steps in that direction.  A huge macaw, flushed from the undergrowth, screams and flies away.  Indian #2 does ex- actly the same thing, never to be seen again. Indy, Satipo and Barranca, just clearing the trees, look back in that direction.  They all turn to face the Temple. It is dark and awesome.  Vegetation curls from every crevice, over each elaborate frieze.  The entrance-- round, open and black--has been designed to look like open jaws.

No!

(a quieter, remote voice) Burning villages.

That's to keep the natives from runnin' away. No place to come back to. Been doin' it all over, they told me up at Limbasi. The Germans are gonna train 'em into an army and try to take over the whole of Africa.
Poor helpless natives!

It was the same up at the mine when I got back from Limbasi. A clean sweep of everything. Just plain luck I was on the river. They could certainly use my launch and what's in 'er, too. Blastin' gelatine, Miss. Eight boxes of it. An' a lot of canned grub. An' cylinders of oxygen an' hydrogen for that weldin' job on the crusher. Lots o' stuff.
(same dead voice) Oh, trust them.

But as it 'appens, I got the stuff -- an' the launch. Only I've got no crew, an' she ain't an easy boat to run single-'anded. Cause them two boys o' mine just skipped in the night. Don't know if they were scared o' me or the Germans.
(quietly, always) They are fiends out of hell... His whole life's work smashed. Ruined. In a few minutes.
The Reverend, eh? (Rose nods) Where's 'e now, Miss?
(pause; quietly) He's dead.
I say, that's too bad! Pretty rough on you, Miss. (embarrassed; trying to keep the ball rolling) What'd 'e die of, Miss?
They killed him.
(really a little surprised and shocked) Well, now that's just awful! If they'll up and shoot a Reverend, who couldn't do 'em a bit a 'arm, there ain't nobody safe.
They didn't shoot him, Mr. Allnutt. But they are accountable to God just as surely as if they had.
'Ow d'you mean, Miss?
They broke his heart. He didn't take care of himself. He didn't want to live.
Well, Miss that's cert'nly too bad, that's all I can say. (both are quiet and he is uneasy in the silence. Making conversation) When'd 'e die, Miss?
Early this morning. (an odd gesture) He's in there.
Hey!
I beg your pardon?
'Scuse it, Miss. (delicately) Wot I mean to say is -- the climate 'n all -- quicker you get 'im under ground the better, if you don't mind me sayin' so.
(getting up) Got a shovel?
Behind the bungalow.
Right. -- Tell ya wot. While I'm diggin' the grave, you get yer things together, Miss -- all the things ya want to take. Then we can clear out of 'ere.

Mother will be so proud, Lord. Abash and put to shame all them that revile me and persecute me for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.

Rapids, Miss. Cataracts and gorges. There's an 'undred miles of rapids down there. Why, the river's even got a different nyme where it comes out on the lake to what it's called up 'ere. It's the Bora down there. No one knew they was the same river until that chap Spengler --

Cause it looks like there's a war on.
(o.s., softly; an almost incapable voice) Rose. Rosie.

Now for the last time, Miss. Just try and listen, won't you? Try to understand. (Rose looks at him coldly; her jaw is set) It's sure death a dozen times over down this river. I 'ate to disappoint you, Miss. But don't blyme me. Blyme the river.

(no answer) Then, too, with me, it's always -- put things orf. Never do todye wot ya can put orf till tomorrer. (he chuckles and looks at her, expecting her to smile. Not a glimmer from Rose) But you  business afore pleasure, every time. Do yer pers'nal laundry, make yerself spic an' span, get all the mendin' out o' the way, an' then, an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice quiet hour with the Good-Book. (he watches for something; she registers nothing) I tell you, it's a model for me, like. An inspiration. I ain't got that ole engine so clean in years; inside an' out, Miss. Just look at 'er, Miss! (no look) Freshens you up, too; if I only 'ad clean clothes, like you. (huh-uh) Now you  why you could be at 'igh tea. (no recognition from Rose) 'Ow 'bout some tea, Miss, come to think of it? Don't you stir; I'll get it ready.
You'd do the same for me, Miss.

So port's always that side -- (gesturing) -- an' starboard, that -- an' forrard's always up there an' aft is where we are right now -- no matter what way we're turned around or the boat is headed.

All the channels we've lost -- an' the twistin' we've done -- we may come back out where we started -- if we come out at all.
Yes.
I dunno. I might. Means workin' underwater. Could do it perhaps.
(talking through this) No, look, Rosie, just look at us! We're movin', don't you see? Movin', that's what!
The bites themselves ain't so bad; it's 'avin' them all round you. I've 'eard of them sendin' buffaloes an' native cattle stark starin' mad -- an' they run an' run till they fall dead.
(just managing to shape the sound) Yes?
I guess that wasn't Ulanga Falls, after all.
Right.
Glad you agree, Rosie. When the time comes I'll put you ashore on the south side of the lake and you wait for me while I attend to The Louisa...
(calling loudly) Mr. Allnutt!
history: (o.s.) Mr. Allnutt.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (shouting as loud as he can) Man the tiller now -- we'll try.
Sure, Miss. Won't do 'em no 'arm.
Mistah Sayuh! Mistah Sayuh!
Be sure you cover up good. Gets a bit chilly on the river, towards mornin'.
(o.s.) Are you ready, Miss?

(a sudden realization. Boozily, sorely) -- Say, who do you think you are, all this we'll do this an' we'll do that? 'Oose boat is this, any'ow? 'Oo asked you aboard? Huh? Huh? You crazy, psalm-singin', skinny old maid.

If my old dad 'ad put me to blacksmithin' when I was a kid, I don't think I should never 'ave come to Africa. I might've -- (a faraway look comes into his eyes; he is thinking about Charing Cross on a Saturday night; finally he shakes himself) -- But then I shouldn't never 'ave met you, Rosie old girl. (he goes back to hammering) I wouldn't trade you for all the fried fish shops in the world.
(o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er drift.
(with a sweeping gesture) Fire!
(o.s.) Now all that little choppin', them's shallas, Miss.
(loud, o.s.) You may come in out of the rain, Mr. Allnutt!
history: (o.s.) Mr. Allnutt.
(calling loudly) Mr. Allnutt!
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (continuing) Great thing to 'ave a lyedy aboard, with clean 'abits. Sets me a good example. A man alone, 'e gets to livin' like a bloomin' 'og. (no answer) Then, too, with me, it's always -- put things orf. Never do todye wot ya can put orf till tomorrer. (he chuckles and looks at her, expecting her to smile. Not a glimmer from Rose) But you  business afore pleasure, every time. Do yer pers'nal laundry, make yerself spic an' span, get all the mendin' out o' the way, an' then, an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice quiet hour with the Good-Book. (he watches for something; she registers nothing) I tell you, it's a model for me, like. An inspiration. I ain't got that ole engine so clean in years; inside an' out, Miss. Just look at 'er, Miss! She practically sparkles. (Rose evidently does not hear him) Myself, too. Guess you ain't never 'ad a look at me without whiskers an' all cleaned up, 'ave you, Miss? (no look) Freshens you up, too; if I only 'ad clean clothes, like you. (huh-uh) Now you  why you could be at 'igh tea. (no recognition from Rose) 'Ow 'bout some tea, Miss, come to think of it? Don't you stir; I'll get it ready.
(eyes shut; a faint, delirious voice) Smite them, Lord! Smite the Amalekites, hip and thigh!

(continuing) 'Ow's the book, Miss? (no answer) Not that I ain't read it, some -- that is to say, me ole lyedy read me stories out of it. (no answer; pause) 'Ow 'bout readin' it out loud, eh, Miss? (silence) I'd like to 'ave a little spiritual comfort m'self. (silence; he flares up) An' you call yerself a Christian! (silence) You 'ear me, Miss. (silence) Don't yer? (silence; a bright cruel idea. Louder, leaning to her) Don't yer? (silence. Suddenly, at the top of his lungs)
Can't say.
(after a while) One thing sure; our men won't come up from the Congo, not even if they want to. They'd 'ave to cross the lake, and nothin' won't cross the lake while The Louisa is there.
(quietly, to Swahili corporal, in Swahili) Order your men to fire.
(awed, and moved) War. England. Just think!
Why, Miss! Is that wot it's all about?
What's the matter?
Charlie.
Certainly, Mr. Allnutt.
history: (o.s.) Mr. Allnutt.
(calling loudly) Mr. Allnutt!
(loud, o.s.) You may come in out of the rain, Mr. Allnutt!
Thanks, Miss.

Yes.
Oh -- not so many miles, but --
(o.s.) Huh?
(o.s. in German) She can't. She is adrift.

(accepting utter defeat) Down the river we go.
Rosie.

(with calm, resolve, acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose. I'm not going to study any more. If I don't pass, it only means that God has other work for me. Thy will be done. (in a different voice, secret, piteous, impassioned) But, Lord, if it be Thy Will, O let me distinguish myself and give me a call here in England, right here at home, Lord. Mother will be so proud, Lord. Abash and put to shame all them that revile me and persecute me for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.
Shucks. Just seemed like he oughta have one, him a Reverend 'n all.
(quietly, impersonally, when the light is very low) 'Night Miss.
(sweat pouring from him, teeth rattling) Why aren't you dressed, Rose? It's time for Service.
Why not?
(continuing) Ain't your property, Miss.
Darling. Dear.
That's quite all right, Mr. Allnutt.

(calling loudly) Mr. Allnutt!

Yes, Mr. Allnutt?
Sorry I give you such a turn.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (with earnest dignity) Lied? Oh no, Miss. Lyin's one thing I don't never do. Not unless there's no way out.
(talking through this) No, look, Rosie, just look at us! We're movin', don't you see? Movin', that's what!
Let's get this water out and see.

(continuing) 'Ow's the book, Miss? (no answer) Not that I ain't read it, some -- that is to say, me ole lyedy read me stories out of it. (no answer; pause) 'Ow 'bout readin' it out loud, eh, Miss? I could not find anything to say.
(quiet desperation) And that is all you can tell us?
Oh, they can't, eh? They got rifles, maybe machine guns, maybe even cannons, an' just one bullet in that blastin' gelatine an', Miss, what's left of us would be in bits and pieces.
Have pity, Miss! (pause; SOUND of "glug- glug" o.s.) Miss? ("glug-glug") Oh, Miss, you don't know what you're doin'... I'll perish without a hair o' the dog.

(continuing) 'Ow's the book, Miss? (no answer) Not that I ain't read it, some -- that is to say, me ole lyedy read me stories out of it. (no answer; pause) 'Ow 'bout readin' it out loud, eh, Miss? (silence; a bright cruel idea. Louder, leaning to her) Don't yer? (silence. Suddenly, at the top of his lungs)

(tremendously amused; gravely) That might work. (humoring her along, and a little taken in by his own fondness for makeshift) Them cylinders'd do right enough. I could let the gas out of 'em and fill 'em up with the gelignite. I could fix up a detonator all right. Revolver cartridge'd do. (warming up to it, as an impossible project) Why, sure, we could cut 'oles in the bows of the launch, and 'ave the cylinders stickin' out through them, so's to get the explosion near the water. Might turn the trick. But what would 'appen to us? It would blow this ole launch and us and everything all to Kingdom come.
Goodnight, Mr. Allnutt.

candidates: (over shoulder) 'Cross our bows, I reckon. Didn't 'it us any'ow.
So cold and so foggy. My eyes are so tired. Where is Rose? Rose, are you down there in the shop? Rose, bring me a cup of hot tea.
(the engineer in him taking over) There's 'eaps an' 'eaps of driftwood up on the bank.
It's 'ot work, ain't it, Miss? I could do with a drink.

It's better than we coulda hoped for. We 'aven't lost nothin', far as I can see. 'Aven't damaged 'er skin worth mentionin'. I shoulda thought there'd been an 'ole in 'er somewheres, after wot she's been through.
(over shoulder; bawling desperately in the silence) Let 'er drift! All we can do!
Yes -- if we can get up steam in time, an' the boiler'll stand that much cold water, an' the mend holds.
(o.s.) Gin, Miss. And there's only river water to drink it with.
I guess that wasn't Ulanga Falls, after all.
I thought they'd seen us.
The river. I never realized before how very strongly it smells.
history: What a frightfully strong smell, isn't it! I suppose it's bound to be at its worst in the middle of the day.
What smell?
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: Thanks, Miss. Night.
Rosie, listen... You 'ear wot I 'ear?
(o.s.) Pull it over this side, I mean. -- That's it! Steady!
(semi-conscious; his jaw not broken but bleeding and already swelling) No. No.
(o.s.) Mistah! Oh Mistah Sayuh!

(rattling on) I spose there's goin' to be a fight. If our troops come from the sea, they'll attack up the railway to Limbasi, I spose. In that case, the best thing we could do would be to wait round down 'ere an' just go up to Limbasi when the time came. -- On the other 'and, they might come down from British East, an' if they do that we'd 'ave the Germans between us and them all the time. Same if they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese East. We're in a bit of a fix, whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?
What's that?
Don't mind if I do.
Let's get this water out and see.
Port a little, Miss.
It's like marigolds. Stale ones.
history: What a frightfully strong smell, isn't it! I suppose it's bound to be at its worst in the middle of the day.

The river. I never realized before how very strongly it smells.
Hmm. So it does, now I notice it. Guess I'm on the water so much, I forget all about it.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (with deeper feeling but quietly; reacting now to what he sees) Oh...!
(teeth chattering) Time, this minute!
The railway was in German 'ands when I was in Limbasi -- and by this time Limbasi is too, I'll bet.
What's that?
Right. -- Tell ya wot. While I'm diggin' the grave, you get yer things together, Miss -- all the things ya want to take. Then we can clear out of 'ere.
(in a suddenly normal and shriveling voice; quietly) Rose.
Rosie, listen... You 'ear wot I 'ear?
(nods) Fancy your building the fire and all -- while I slept.
(after a pause) Miss...
(a whimpering moan, pure misery; not for what he sees) Oh... Oh...!

(rage, shock, astonishment) No!

(brightly) Well, Miss, 'ere we are, everything ship-shape, like they say.

Shaft is ready to come out now. It'll be too heavy for me to swim up with. I'll 'ave to walk with it in to shore... Well, 'ere goes -- for the last time, I 'ope.
You be ready to -- but I'd like to try it.

(with deeper feeling but quietly; reacting now to what he sees) Oh...!
Mend it! (he laughs bitterly) Not likely.

It turns right enough. But that don't prove nothin' much. Will it stand up under a full head of steam, that's the question. We'll get our answer out there -- and Lord 'elp us if it ain't the right one.

Miss, I'm sorry. I 'pologize. There. What more can a man do than say he's sorry. Eh? (no answer) You done paid me back, Miss. Didn't even leave me a drop. (no answer) Come on, Miss. 'Ave a 'eart, can't ya? Fair's fair. (no answer) Miss, I don't care wot ya say, long 's you say somepin. (no answer) I'll be honest with ya, Miss  I just can't stand no more of it. I ain't used to it, that's all.
All dat hell-fish!
(yelling) Heyy!!

Ever get 'omesick?

(silence) I'd like to 'ave a little spiritual comfort m'self. (silence; he flares up) An' you call yerself a Christian! (silence) You 'ear me, Miss. (silence) Don't yer? (silence; a bright cruel idea. Louder, leaning to her) Don't yer? (silence. Suddenly, at the top of his lungs)
(very quietly) There, there, Rosie. There, old girl. We're all right now, dear. There, there.
(o.s. in German) Probably they're making for the lower landing.
(in a voice like a crow) Miss.

Stop, Charlie -- stop it!
history: (in a broken voice) Give us another kiss, old girl.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er drift.
Forrard, Miss. I can fix up a sorta bed outa them cases.
(with earnest dignity) Lied? Oh no, Miss. Lyin's one thing I don't never do. Not unless there's no way out.

I know wot you're thinkin' 'bout doin'. (he takes her hand and presses it) You're thinkin' 'bout takin' The African Queen out at night next time The Louisa comes 'ere, ain't you, old girl? (Rose nods) We ought to manage it.
(o.s.) Huh?
(o.s., softly; an almost incapable voice) Rose. Rosie.
(with deep feeling) Better'n all right, Miss...
(quietly, impersonally, when the light is very low) 'Night Miss.

(soberly) I guess not.

utterances.name: ROSE

(very quietly) There, there, Rosie. There, old girl. We're all right now, dear. There, there.

In that case, the best thing we could do would be to wait round down 'ere an' just go up to Limbasi when the time came. -- On the other 'and, they might come down from British East, an' if they do that we'd 'ave the Germans between us and them all the time. Same if they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese East. We're in a bit of a fix, whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?
(o.s. in German) She is adrift.

Rosie, old girl -- Rosie --

(continuing) Great thing to 'ave a lyedy aboard, with clean 'abits. Sets me a good example. A man alone, 'e gets to livin' like a bloomin' 'og. (no answer) Then, too, with me, it's always -- put things orf. Never do todye wot ya can put orf till tomorrer. (he chuckles and looks at her, expecting her to smile. Not a glimmer from Rose) But you  business afore pleasure, every time. Do yer pers'nal laundry, make yerself spic an' span, get all the mendin' out o' the way, an' then, an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice quiet hour with the Good-Book. (he watches for something; she registers nothing) I tell you, it's a model for me, like. An inspiration. I ain't got that ole engine so clean in years; inside an' out, Miss. Just look at 'er, Miss! She practically sparkles. (Rose evidently does not hear him) Myself, too. Guess you ain't never 'ad a look at me without whiskers an' all cleaned up, 'ave you, Miss? (no look) Freshens you up, too; if I only 'ad clean clothes, like you. (huh-uh) Now you  why you could be at 'igh tea. (no recognition from Rose) 'Ow 'bout some tea, Miss, come to think of it? Don't you stir; I'll get it ready.

(accepting utter defeat) Down the river we go.

(in a suddenly normal and shriveling voice; quietly) Rose.

(mimicking her tone, nastily) Shona! (pause) If there's any place along the whole river the Germans'll keep a lookout, it'll be Shona. 'Cause that's where the old road ferries over from the South.

(all innocence) Yes?
(in quick agreement) I've got a can o' paint for 'er mast. She ought to look 'er best. 'Er very best. Representin' as she does the Royal Navy.
(after a pause) Can't you get the shaft out without pulling the boat on shore?

I'll tell ya. (savage despondency in his tone) I'll tell ya what we could do if we was sittin' in the landin' slip at Limbasi. We could pull this old tub out an' take the shaft down an' 'aul it over to the workshop where they'd forge it straight again. An' then we could write to the makers and get a new prop. They might 'ave one in stock 'cause this boat ain't over thirty years old. An' while we was waitin' we might clean 'er bottom an' paint 'er. Then we could put in the shaft an' the new prop an' launch 'er an' go on as if nothin' 'ad 'appened. -- But this ain't Limbasi, an' so we can't.

(in a friendly, yet detached tone) Just listen to that stomick of mine.

Then we could put in the shaft an' the new prop an' launch 'er an' go on as if nothin' 'ad 'appened. -- But this ain't Limbasi, an' so we can't.
(after a pause) Can't you get the shaft out without pulling the boat on shore?
I dunno. I might. Means workin' underwater. Could do it perhaps.
Well, if you were able to get the shaft up on shore, could you straighten it?
Ain't got no hearth. Ain't got no anvil. Ain't got no coal. Ain't got nothin'. An' furthermore, I ain't no blacksmith.
(tapping her memory) I saw a Masai native working once. Using charcoal... on a big hollow stone. He had a boy to fan the charcoal.
Yes, I've seen that, too! But I'd use a bellows, myself -- make them easy enough.
Well, if you think that would be better.
(the engineer in him taking over) There's 'eaps an' 'eaps of driftwood up on the bank.
Why don't you try it?
(suddenly shying) No. It ain't no use, Rosie, old girl. I was forgettin' that prop. There's a blade gone.

Oh, Germany, England, the whole --
(awed, and moved) War. England. Just think!
Musta been 'Im, all right -- 'tweren't nothin' in our power.

It's better than we coulda hoped for. We 'aven't lost nothin', far as I can see. 'Aven't damaged 'er skin worth mentionin'. I shoulda thought there'd been an 'ole in 'er somewheres, after wot she's been through.

(with calm, resolve, acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose. I'm not going to study any more. If I don't pass, it only means that God has other work for me. Thy will be done. (in a different voice, secret, piteous, impassioned) But, Lord, if it be Thy Will, O let me distinguish myself and give me a call here in England, right here at home, Lord. Mother will be so proud, Lord. Abash and put to shame all them that revile me and persecute me for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.
(yelling) Heyy!!
(o.s., softly; an almost incapable voice) Rose. Rosie.
Look at us, Rosie! My God just look! We're movin', dear! We're movin'!
(calmly, in German) Speak German, please; I speak no English.
We'll have to make another blade. There's lots of iron and stuff you could use.

I'll 'ave to go underneath and 'ave a look.
There ain't no other way. You stay 'andy with that rope -- case there's a fancy current down at the bottom... 'Ere goes!

Yes.

We'll have to mend it, then.
Mend it! (he laughs bitterly) Not likely.

candidates: Thanks, Miss.
(boiling mad, the innocent courage of a lion) What is the meaning of this outrage!

Perhaps I should. I feel rather odd.

(feeling his oats and his gin; mimicking nastily) What an absurd idea! What an absurd idea! Lady, I may be a born fool, but you got ten absurd idears to my one, an' don't you forget it! (pause. Speechless with scorn and resentment) Huh!
Rosie, listen... You 'ear wot I 'ear?
(yelling) Heyy!!
(missing his irony) Yes, if you think that will do. But wouldn't it be better to -- weld it? That's the right word, isn't it? Weld it on?

Bless you, no, Miss, that's safety stuff, that is. It can get wet and not do any 'arm. If you set fire to it, it just burns. You can 'it it wiv an 'ammer and it won't go off -- at least I don't fink it will. It takes a detonator to set it off. I'll put it over the side if it worries you though.
Rosie.
Shucks. Just seemed like he oughta have one, him a Reverend 'n all.
We nearly done it that time, didn't we, Rosie.
(o.s.) Mistah! Oh Mistah Sayuh!
(turning, murmuring) Sorry I woke you, Miss.

utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: It's 'ot work, ain't it, Miss? I could do with a drink.
(without spirit) Not so bad, Miss, considerin'. But that wasn't such bad water -- nothin' compared to what's farther on.
(o.s.) That's The Louisa.
Yerss...?
Nothin' you'd understand.
(o.s.) I'll turn out the light if you're ready, Miss.
(in a broken voice) Give us another kiss, old girl.
(in German) Fire at random.

You got me, Miss. (after a pause) We've got 'eaps of grub 'ere, Miss, so we're all right, far as that goes. Two thousand cigarettes, two cases of gin. We could find a good 'iding place an' stay there for months if we want to.
(in a voice like a crow) Miss.
You were down there an awfully long time. I got scared.
history: (gasping) Swallered about half the river that time.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (nods) Fancy your building the fire and all -- while I slept.

(rattling on) I spose there's goin' to be a fight. If our troops come from the sea, they'll attack up the railway to Limbasi, I spose. In that case, the best thing we could do would be to wait round down 'ere an' just go up to Limbasi when the time came. -- On the other 'and, they might come down from British East, an' if they do that we'd 'ave the Germans between us and them all the time. Same if they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese East. We're in a bit of a fix, whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?

(with calm, resolve, acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose. I'm not going to study any more. If I don't pass, it only means that God has other work for me. Thy will be done. Right.
Blimey, Miss!
(in German) Give it to me.
(the engineer in him taking over) There's 'eaps an' 'eaps of driftwood up on the bank.
(after a pause) Miss...
Thanks, Miss.
The blade's a different proposition. I'll 'ave to make it.
Charlie.
history: (gasping) Swallered about half the river that time.
You were down there an awfully long time. I got scared.
Shaft is ready to come out now. It'll be too heavy for me to swim up with. I'll 'ave to walk with it in to shore... Well, 'ere goes -- for the last time, I 'ope.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: What do I want to blow up sumpin' for? You tell me. Yeah. You tell me. That's all!
(o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er drift.

(continuing) Great thing to 'ave a lyedy aboard, with clean 'abits. Sets me a good example. A man alone, 'e gets to livin' like a bloomin' 'og. (no answer) Then, too, with me, it's always -- put things orf. Never do todye wot ya can put orf till tomorrer. (he chuckles and looks at her, expecting her to smile. Not a glimmer from Rose) But you  business afore pleasure, every time. Do yer pers'nal laundry, make yerself spic an' span, get all the mendin' out o' the way, an' then, an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice quiet hour with the Good-Book. (he watches for something; she registers nothing) I tell you, it's a model for me, like. An inspiration. I ain't got that ole engine so clean in years; inside an' out, Miss. Just look at 'er, Miss! She practically sparkles. (Rose evidently does not hear him) Myself, too. Guess you ain't never 'ad a look at me without whiskers an' all cleaned up, 'ave you, Miss? (no look) Freshens you up, too; if I only 'ad clean clothes, like you. (huh-uh) Now you  why you could be at 'igh tea. (no recognition from Rose) 'Ow 'bout some tea, Miss, come to think of it? Don't you stir; I'll get it ready.
(nodding) Just before we 'it, I'll bring the ballast back forrard.
If a bullet hits them boxes, there'll be no time to worry.
Can't put them into the cylinders yet. They're a bit tricky. We can put 'em in when we're all ready to start.
(eyes shut; a faint, delirious voice) Smite them, Lord! Smite the Amalekites, hip and thigh!
(sweat pouring from him, teeth rattling) Why aren't you dressed, Rose? It's time for Service.
(bewildered) Well -- wot else?
I thought they'd seen us.
Let me help you.
history: (gasping) Swallered about half the river that time.

Charlie.
Huh?
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (in German) Fire at random.

Now for the last time, Miss. Just try and listen, won't you? Try to understand. (Rose looks at him coldly; her jaw is set) It's sure death a dozen times over down this river. I 'ate to disappoint you, Miss. But don't blyme me. Blyme the river.
(rage, shock, astonishment) No!
'Ave one, Miss?
The railway was in German 'ands when I was in Limbasi -- and by this time Limbasi is too, I'll bet.
I don't remember very much about the Sundays. I was always sleeping it off.
Let's get this water out and see.
Huh?

This 'ere storm is messing things up a bit. 'Er bows 'ave got to ride 'igh or we'll be swamped before we get 'alf way to The Louisa. On the other 'and, they've got to be low when we 'it 'er, so' the explosion will be down at 'er waterline.
(teeth chattering) Time, this minute!
Go down with you.
history: (gasping) Swallered about half the river that time.
You were down there an awfully long time. I got scared.

Charlie.
Huh?
Let me help you.
'Ow do you mean?
Wot d'you think you're goin' to do?
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (after a pause; scornfully) Huh!
You're catchin' on fine, Miss.
That don't mean nothin' -- with this river. This river's crazy. Crazy as I am!
(eyes shut; a faint, delirious voice) Smite them, Lord! Smite the Amalekites, hip and thigh!
'Scuse it, Miss. (delicately) Wot I mean to say is -- the climate 'n all -- quicker you get 'im under ground the better, if you don't mind me sayin' so.
(eyes shut; a faint, delirious voice) Smite them, Lord! Smite the Amalekites, hip and thigh!
Thanks, Miss. Night.
(after a pause; scornfully) Huh!
(o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er drift.

I try to study -- so hard. I haven't had the start some have  'Ebrew; Greek -- no -- facility. If only there were more time. Well, if I can't pass the examinations, I can volunteer. I can be a missionary. Rose, too. Not comely among maidens, but she can become a servant in the house of the Lord. Yes, even for such as she, God finds a goodly use.
(protesting this accolade) Oh, Charlie!
history: If my old dad 'ad put me to blacksmithin' when I was a kid, I don't think I should never 'ave come to Africa. I might've -- (a faraway look comes into his eyes; he is thinking about Charing Cross on a Saturday night; finally he shakes himself) -- But then I shouldn't never 'ave met you, Rosie old girl. (he goes back to hammering) I wouldn't trade you for all the fried fish shops in the world.
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (just managing to shape the sound) Yes?

(tremendously amused; gravely) That might work. (humoring her along, and a little taken in by his own fondness for makeshift) Them cylinders'd do right enough. I could let the gas out of 'em and fill 'em up with the gelignite. I could fix up a detonator all right. Revolver cartridge'd do. (warming up to it, as an impossible project) Why, sure, we could cut 'oles in the bows of the launch, and 'ave the cylinders stickin' out through them, so's to get the explosion near the water. Might turn the trick. But what would 'appen to us? It would blow this ole launch and us and everything all to Kingdom come.
(awed, and moved) War. England. Just think!
(shouting) Well, I'm takin' my promise back!
What smell?

(with a sweeping gesture) Fire!
(in snaggle-toothed, adoring enthusiasm) Oh Mistah Sayuh, I does like how you preach!
(o.s. in German) But why didn't they put in?

Only a week.

Yes.
(in German) Fire at random.
(o.s.) Gin, Miss. And there's only river water to drink it with.
(o.s.) Just turn 'er loose, Miss. Let 'er drift.
(shouting as loud as he can) Man the tiller now -- we'll try.
Yes, I've seen that, too! But I'd use a bellows, myself -- make them easy enough.

Let's find out right now.

(shouting) Well, I'm takin' my promise back!
Looks like this old river got tired of all that runnin' an' jumpin' she did an' decided to lay down an' rest for a while... 'Ow about our doin' the same, Rosie -- seein' as 'ow the sun's goin' down.
Oh, Germany, England, the whole --
(with earnest dignity) Lied? Oh no, Miss. Lyin's one thing I don't never do. Not unless there's no way out.
(turning, murmuring) Sorry I woke you, Miss.
(o.s.) I'll turn out the light if you're ready, Miss.
No offence, Miss.
(just managing to shape the sound) Yes?
All right -- but don't wear yourself out... I'll pick up some wood.
Goodbye, darling.

candidates: (with deeper feeling but quietly; reacting now to what he sees) Oh...!
Easy, Rosie dear! You just rest, old girl. Easy now.
(irate -- we sense a background of unpleasant relations with the Germans) In heaven's name why?
Sorry, old girl.

If it wasn't for The Louisa, there wouldn't be nothin' to it. The Germans couldn't last a month if our men could get across the lake... But all this doesn't get us any nearer 'ome, does it, Miss? Believe me, if I could think wot we could do...
Give us another kiss.
Let's get this water out and see.
(suddenly shying) No. It ain't no use, Rosie, old girl. I was forgettin' that prop. There's a blade gone.

I know wot you're thinkin' 'bout doin'. (he takes her hand and presses it) You're thinkin' 'bout takin' The African Queen out at night next time The Louisa comes 'ere, ain't you, old girl? (Rose nods) We ought to manage it.

I try to study -- so hard. I haven't had the start some have  'Ebrew; Greek -- no -- facility. If only there were more time. Well, if I can't pass the examinations, I can volunteer. (indignantly) No, of course not. Look at the way you made the engine go. Look how you mended the propeller. It wasn't me at all. (with even greater emphasis) I don't think there's another man alive who could have done it.
history: Well, we done it, old girl. We got down the rapids all right. I didn't think it could be done. If it 'adn't been for you, sweetheart, we shouldn't be 'ere now. Don't you feel proud of yourself, dear?
utterances.name: ROSE

candidates: (o.s. in German) Probably they're making for the lower landing.
I guess that wasn't Ulanga Falls, after all.
It reminds me -- that waterfall does -- of --
(with a sweeping gesture) Fire!
(talking through this) No, look, Rosie, just look at us! We're movin', don't you see? Movin', that's what!

(wryly) I don't think anyone's likely to try.
Looks like this old river got tired of all that runnin' an' jumpin' she did an' decided to lay down an' rest for a while... 'Ow about our doin' the same, Rosie -- seein' as 'ow the sun's goin' down.

Yes! That's it!

(after a pause) What are we going to do, Charlie?
Now you're asking!

(rattling on) I spose there's goin' to be a fight. If our troops come from the sea, they'll attack up the railway to Limbasi, I spose. Same if they came from Rhodesia or Portuguese East. We're in a bit of a fix, whichever way y'look at it, Miss. (abruptly) Mind takin' the tiller, Miss?

Mistah Sayuh! Mistah Sayuh!

You got me, Miss. (after a pause) We've got 'eaps of grub 'ere, Miss, so we're all right, far as that goes. Two thousand cigarettes, two cases of gin. We could find a good 'iding place an' stay there for months if we want to.
Right. -- Tell ya wot. While I'm diggin' the grave, you get yer things together, Miss -- all the things ya want to take. Then we can clear out of 'ere.
All the channels we've lost -- an' the twistin' we've done -- we may come back out where we started -- if we come out at all.

Yes -- if we can get up steam in time, an' the boiler'll stand that much cold water, an' the mend holds.

I can get the stuff into the tubes in no time, as you might say. Don't know 'bout the detonators. Gotta make them up, you see -- devise something. Then we got to cut 'oles in the bows. Might 'ave it all done in three days. Depends on them detonators.

(with calm, resolve, acceptance) I'm going to put my books away, Rose. I'm not going to study any more. If I don't pass, it only means that God has other work for me. Thy will be done. (in a different voice, secret, piteous, impassioned) But, Lord, if it be Thy Will, O let me distinguish myself and give me a call here in England, right here at home, Lord. Mother will be so proud, Lord. Abash and put to shame all them that revile me and persecute me for Thy Name's sake. (whispering; pleading) Lord, I have tried so hard.

(continuing) 'Ow's the book, Miss? (no answer) Not that I ain't read it, some -- that is to say, me ole lyedy read me stories out of it. (no answer; pause) 'Ow 'bout readin' it out loud, eh, Miss? (silence) I'd like to 'ave a little spiritual comfort m'self. (silence; he flares up) An' you call yerself a Christian! (silence) You 'ear me, Miss. (silence) Don't yer? (silence; a bright cruel idea. Louder, leaning to her) Don't yer? (silence. Suddenly, at the top of his lungs)
Let's get this water out and see.

If my old dad 'ad put me to blacksmithin' when I was a kid, I don't think I should never 'ave come to Africa. I might've -- (a faraway look comes into his eyes; he is thinking about Charing Cross on a Saturday night; finally he shakes himself) -- But then I shouldn't never 'ave met you, Rosie old girl. (he goes back to hammering) I wouldn't trade you for all the fried fish shops in the world.

An' get drownded? You don't know wot it's like, Rosie. Them currents is just fierce. (he shakes his head) Wot'll you be thinkin' of next! (he takes two deep breaths) Well, 'ere goes. (After a third and deeper breath, he is gone.)

Do yer pers'nal laundry, make yerself spic an' span, get all the mendin' out o' the way, an' then, an' hone-ly then, set down to a nice quiet hour with the Good-Book. Don't move, asshole. Don't even breathe.
I don't care. i don't want it.
The Kurgans were an ancient people from the steppes of Russia. For amusement, they tossed children into pits with hungry dogs to fight for meat.
What do you do with it?
I am that, my love.

That black knight was the Kurgan. It is because of him that I sought you out. (MacLeod blinks) There is great power in the Quickening. But Nature has not given us equal shares. Some, like you and the Kurgan, have more.
Hey!  Where ya goin'?
(struggling) Don't see me, Conner. Let me die in peace.
history: My beautiful man. My husband.
I am that, my love.
I have never...really known.
What?
Why you stayed.
Because I love you as much now as the day I first met you.
And I love you.
I want that, too.
Will you do something for me, Conner
What, blossom?
In years to come, will you light a candle and remember me on my birthday?
Aye, love. I will
I wanted to have your children.
(huskily) They would have been strong and fine.
utterances.name: HEATHER

candidates: (suspiciously) What is it?
In the end, there can be only one. (swinging) It is the Prize for which we all struggle. The Kurgan must never win it. Alone, I cannot stop him. (retreating) You may have a chance.
(nodding) Yes. She was an orphan. I can't have children. I adopted her. (drolly) Over the years, our relationship has gone through qquite a few changes.
With heart, faith and steel.
(shouting) Who are you?
Frank, I saw the corpse. The black guy was the same dude who was with Nash. I spent the night with them, for Christ's sake.
Helluva fight, ain'it? Helluva fight. Lotta fun, ain'it?
Haggis? What is haggis?
Such a brave warrior (suddenly ice-cold) Let's see how you can handle the real thing.

If I could verify the existence of such a weapon, it'd be like finding a 747 made a thousand years before the Wright brothers flew. (drolly) With a find like that, I could get on "Good Morning America".

My beautiful man. My husband -- (cheering crowd) Lotta fun, ain't it --? (cannon-fire) Devil! Devil --! (police sirens) Head chopped off two nights ago -- (horns blaring) 600 B.C. It's not supposed to exist -- (a baby crying) Tell them I'm immortal -- (pipes and drums) There can be only one --!
history: You were right, haggis. There will never be another.
